data.text: How to Build Strength for Hike a Bike (Bikepacking)?

How to build strength for hike a bike!?!?! Planning an extended trip in the Andes (up to 5 months) and prospect of extensive hike a bike at high elevation is daunting!! I am small (5"2, 53kg.) And my bike plus gear will weigh upwards of 25kg. Any training tips (aside from the obvious of pushing my bike fully loaded up a hill) that will help me build the muscle I need? Picture is for attention.... I will be using this bike but with WAY more gear.
Go to Colorado, get as high as possible and ride around up there until you don't feel like passing out constantly.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: If you're in the US.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: in Australia. So we don't have anywhere at super high altitude
data.author: Tamz In

data.text: Hit the high country, like the Hunt 100 course maybe? It'll get you used to climbing at least. I guess plan for 1-2 weeks of acclimitization in the Andes?
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: any trails there you'd recommend? I want to cross the Americas, and looking for ideas.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Sorry, no! I live in South Korea. I just know that parts of the Rockies would help to prepare for the Andes.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: Press ups are well worth doing, as they mimic the press action of pushing a loaded bike forward. Calf raises are worthwhile too. And simply spending time pushing a loaded bike up steep hills helps a lot. Pushing a bike up really technical singletrack is a great way to train too, as you'll have to lift and manoeuver it, which helps with both technique and core strength.
data.author: Mark Watson

data.text: No need, you'll be fit enough after the first couple of passes
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: Also, if you're doing the most common Andean bikepacking routes (TEMBR, Peru Divide, etc), there's not a lot of hike a bike.
data.author: Mark Watson

data.text: My cycle training coach’s motto in NZ was… ‘finish your training with some hills. Then, when you have finished training in hills, go do some hills!’ We also used to ‘run off the bike’… ie we’d do our cycle training (road and mtb) then we’d run some or all of the hill circuit we’d just done. As for altitude- you could condition your lungs with something like a powerBreathe, but that doesn’t really cover lack of O2 but good for your lung muscles and diaphragm (which also tire under sustained exertion). Other than that there are O2 deprivation tents you can rent - but you need to be careful - or it’s finding somewhere high. Lastly, remember, you will acclimatise as you go as asking as a) you don’t go to high too quickly and/or b) you don’t fly in to altitude (start your trip high). Safe travels.
data.author: Matt Hickey

data.text: Weight lifting and Pilates
data.author: Susan Young

data.text: To be honest...just simulate hike a bike on your local hill with fully loaded bike...This way you will get used to exactly what is ahead of you and you will also train those muscles you will need. After first session you will get the idea what muscles are weakest and you can work on it in a gym:)
data.author: Rok Pajer

data.text: Pilates and focus on Core Strength. Your back and pelvic muscles are key
data.author: Crispin Smith

data.text: All core exercises are great.
data.author: Brian Gallagher

data.text: Work on muscular strength and endurance. Indoor exercises: upper body - press ups, shoulder press, pull/drag weighted trolly, triceps extensions. Lower body - dead lifts, good mornings, squats things like this. Exercise uses that include pushing away and above the body. Outdoors: hike your bike up any hill you can find. Over weigh your bike during training so when you do go it'll be lighter.
data.author: Harry Boe

data.text: Have someone steer your car whilst you push it up and down car park.
data.author: Howard Peel

data.text: Good luck you tiny thing you
data.author: John Findlay

data.text: My plan is different. I am working on a setup that has a backpack strapped on the rear, which can easily be moved onto my back. Makes it much easier for hike a bike.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: hmmm very interesting idea. I might have to try that out
data.author: Tamz In

data.text: I know others who do this. It also allows you to go backpacking. Main thing is to limit the bag to 30 liters, and get a large handlebar bag for less dense gear that takes up more space.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text:
other option would be to carry a low weight collapsible backpack that folds really small into your handlebar bag. Maybe something like this? Peak Gear Foldable Backpack - Compact Packable Day Pack - Includes Lifetime Lost & Found ID https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07F1ZV81Q/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_i_DW9ZQ4GK2SX4YMCCZY2Y
Peak Gear Foldable Backpack - Compact Packable Day Pack - Includes Lifetime Lost & Found ID
amazon.com
data.author: Mark Wilson

data.text: guessing you my misunderstood my comment. The idea is to be able to quickly shift weight from the bike to your back when doing hike a bike. The pack should be loaded on the bag. It's like removing your panniers and carrying them separately, but in this case you can do it all in one go. And possibly even shoulder the bike if the remaining load isn't too much.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: that makes sense. I use a backpacker seat bag instead of panniers. Best wishes for a successful event.
data.author: Mark Wilson

data.text: Squats!!! Get some resistance training in. If your unsure on technique or what movements to do have a session with a PT or Coach. It will make a huge difference. Running is also savage for building strength and cardio, but focus on form and just building up the distance over 30 minutes or so every couple of days 💪🔥🔥🔥
data.author: Thomas Cornes

data.text: Maybe try running sprints up hill. Push ups or military presses to build some arm strength for pushing over obstacles when tired. I would also suggest trying to reduce the amount of gear you will be taking if possible.
data.author: Eric Kozokas

data.text:
Ray Jardine trained for pulling a sled to the South Pole dragging a truck tire. https://www.rayjardine.com/adventures/2006-SouthPole/index.php?StoryPage=1
Skiing to the South Pole in 59 days : Ray & Jenny Jardine
rayjardine.com
data.author: Ira Holston

data.text: Usually for me the first week of the trip is the training.
data.author: Bruce Law

data.text: I hope your shoes are solid and comfy. The rest just is. Oh... I think my PT exercises for my shoulder are pretty great for hike a biking. Gets all those little muscles you'll be working. The big ones will be fine. Remember to be good to your neck.
data.author: Kristina Coyne

data.text: I’m a runner and a hiker first, so being able to get off the bike and hike is a nice break sometimes. But use shoes with traction. I pushed my bike up all kinds of hills in the Alps.
data.author: Jacob Buller

data.text: Find good hills and ride more.
data.author: Guizhou Li

data.text: Hi Tamz, I rode for 6 months in Colombia and Peru. If you plan to take off roads (gravel) you can make most off it riding. Some climbs can take hours, what i did was to rely more on cardio, I use a 28t chainring with 50t low cassette, at high altitude and big climbs go at your own confortable pace, good cadence and patience. The good views will help 🏔️🏔️.
data.author: Daniel Castaño

data.text: When pushing bike, keep switching sides.
data.author: Aaron Denberg

data.text: Push in mud going uphill in a rain storm
data.author: Chuck Jacobs

data.text: after staying awake all of the previous night listening to high wind and rains soundtrack on YouTube.
data.author: William Hughes

data.text: Not training but a tip. One hand one the handlebar and the other on the seat, or in the case of your bike packing setup, the seat post. This will help you posture and allow you to push the bike vs pulling it uphill. And I agree with the switch sides advice above.
data.author: Al Christensen

data.text: Take your time. Enjoy the push. Cause you have to do it whether you enjoy it or not
data.author: Stacey Nieder

data.text: Apply good body mechanics. Figure the most efficient method for you.take your bike to a singletrack area and practice hiking with it. What strains the most, then tweak your method
data.author: Joseph Lynch

data.text: Takes time to acclimate to altitude-it’s not that practical to train at low elevation sufficiently to acclimate. Go there, acclimate and enjoy the mountains. Take your time at altitude, rushing it is no fun at all.
data.author: Tom Pogson

data.text: youmust be ready to carry it.
data.author: Sandy Hague

data.text: Make up a strap, so that you have one hand on the bars a d the other through the strap to pull the bike. I have mine attached to the rear of my tailfin. I put my hand through it like trekking pole.
data.author: Roger Norton

data.text: Pack light and practice. It depends on your route but you shouldn't need to hike a bike too much unless you want to take very challenging routes. You should be able to acclimate to the elevation after a week or so
data.author: Jacob Ashton

data.text: Squats, lunges, push ups and core exercises will all help you. HIIT intervals would also be great.
data.author: Marc Belair
